introduction.p: In this activity we use function notation to describe the characteristics and behavior of a function.
The prerequisites for this lesson are knowing how to read and write inequalities.

subsection.title: Function Characteristics
subsection.p: A function can be positive or negative.

On a graph, if the output values of a function are above the horizontal axis, we say the function is positive. If the output values of a function are below the horizontal axis, we say the function is negative.positive functionfunctionpositivenegative functionfunctionnegative. If the output value is zero, touching the horizontal axis, we say the function is zero (neither positive nor negative).

subsection.p: A function can be increasing or decreasing.

If the output values of the function increase as the input increases, we say the function is increasing. If the output values of the function decrease as the input increases, we say the function is decreasingincreasing functionfunctionincreasingdecreasing functionfunctiondecreasing.
Reading the graph from left-to-right, a function is increasing if its graph goes up and decreasing if its graph goes down.

subsection.p: A function can be concave up or concave down.

If a function curves upward (like a cup that holds water), we say the function is concave up. If a function curves downward (like an inverted cup that does not hold water), we say the function is concave down.concave up functionfunctionconcave upconcave down functionfunctionconcave downconcavity

Another way to think about concavity is to imagine a straight metal wire. While one end of the wire is fixed, if the other end is pushed up the wire is now concave up. If that other end is pushed down the wire is concave down.

statement.p: A rock is dropped, and it falls for 10 seconds before hitting the ground.
The function h(t) represents the height of the rock in feet, where t represents the number of seconds it has been falling.

hint.p: Sketch a graph of this height function. Does it ever have a negative output?
The rock speeds up as it falls, so its height changes more for each second it falls. Can you show this on the graph?

solution.p: While it falls, the function is always positive (it doesn't sink underground), but it is decreasing and concave down (curved steeper and steeper downward).

The function T(t) represents the temperature of the item in degrees Fahrenheit, where t represents the number of minutes it has been out of the freezer.
Choose the descriptions which match this function when t \le 0.

hint.p: Sketch a graph of this temperature function. Is it ever negative?
The temperature changes the fastest immediately after t = 0, but then begins to slow down.

solution.p: This function is always positive and always increasing, but it is concave down (steep to start, but then less steep as time increases).
